abstract.text: An abstract base class for creating graphics renderers.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Don’t use
directly. Instead, either use one of the concrete subclasses (
or
), or create your own subclass.

Graphics renderers provide memory-efficient management of Core Graphics contexts. Core Graphics contexts represent the drawing environment and backing store for 2D Graphics. As you reuse a graphics renderer, it in turn reuses Core Graphics contexts.
You can’t use
directly, but if the concrete subclasses (
and
) don’t provide the functionality you require, you can create your own subclass.
Consider creating a subclass any time you need to create multiple Core Graphics contexts, each with the same dimensions and attributes, and one of the concrete subclasses (
or
) doesn’t provide the functionality you require.
To create a subclass of
, first import the appropriate submodule or header, as shown in the following code.
A graphics renderer manages a pool of Core Graphics contexts that are reused with repeated uses of the renderer. The renderer creates these
objects using the
class method, and then wraps each of them in an instance of the class returned by the
class method. You must therefore override these two methods in your graphics renderer subclass.
To perform drawing actions on a Core Graphics context, call the
method, providing two blocks. Both of these blocks have a
argument, providing access to a Core Graphics context.
It is recommended that you create a public method on your renderer subclass that internally wraps the
method. This is how the rendering methods operate on the concrete subclasses, for example the
method on
Each time the
method is called, the renderer calls the
method with the
and
as arguments. Override the
method to apply the
configuration to the underlying
before the renderer invokes the drawing actions.

abstract.text: A Quartz 2D drawing environment.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A closure that executes a set of drawing instructions that the renderer applies to the Core Graphics context.
A graphics renderer for creating Core Graphics-backed images.
Creates an image from a set of drawing instructions.
The drawing environment for an image renderer.
A set of drawing attributes that represents the configuration of an image renderer context.
A graphics renderer for creating PDFs.
The drawing environment for a PDF renderer.
A set of drawing attributes that represents the configuration of a PDF renderer context.
An abstract base class for creating graphics renderers.
A Boolean value specifying whether the renderer can create output images.
Creates a Core Graphics context configured according to the supplied format object.
The format used to create the graphics renderer.
Creates a new graphics renderer with the specified bounds and a default format.
Creates a new graphics renderer with the given bounds and format.
Applies the configuration specified in the renderer context to the Core Graphics context.
Specifies the drawing context class used by this graphics renderer.
Performs drawing actions on a Core Graphics context that the renderer prepares.
The base class for the drawing environments for graphics renderers.
A set of drawing attributes that represents the configuration of a graphics renderer context.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
